Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: I developed a better understanding of my working/management style, how to best give/receive feedback, and the dynamics around networking and stakeholder engagement.
Understanding myself, managing a team, how to network

I was able to gain a lot of insight on myself and how I work in teams and professional environments which is extremely important. I also gained valuable insight from our professors and guest speakers for the course.
Framework for building interpersonal, communications, teamwork, and networking skills.
I love Amy, Ony and Cass's sessions on how to find meaningful work and bring it to fruition in my organization/workplace.

I learned more about my personality, what kind of work environment I prefer and what type of people I work best with. I also learned where I can improve. The course has helped me become more direct with people professionally and in my personal relationships. I feel much more confident in myself after taking this course.
I learned a great deal about social psychology, myself, and some strategies for how to work in teams.

I especially enjoyed the part of the course on forming coalitions. I also liked the speakers series format, but I did not find the readings super useful. The insights discovery portion was interesting as well.

I think this class provided several templates for how to work with people within various different settings. I thought the readings and guest lecturers together provided both best practices and real life approaches to working with people. I really enjoyed the authentic responses that all of our lecturers gave regarding how to work with people.
Working with people

My own abilities at work
How to work with groups
How to make the best out of my networks and push for change
personal insights into personality, leadership style, management and future desired skills and network areas to grow.
Too many to list! Communication skills, stakeholder engagement, vision and mission, effectuating influence without power, networks and group dynamics, etc.
This class covered the difficult aspects of working and leading teams.

this is a great class. It is an opportunity to reflect on how you work with other people, and it provides tangible skills to help you improve interpersonal skills, effective leadership, and the ability to work in a team.

Insights about myself (strengths and weaknesses in working with people), best practices for dealing with teams in situations such as: assuming a position in a new company where you are the outsider coming in, developing a structure for an organization, inciting change within an organization.
None. I found the class uninformative. It was too general, vague, and commonsensical.

This course has deepened my understanding of self and how I relate to others. The many tools and discussions held on personal experiences will always be useful in life (i.e. communication, feedback, relationship building, cultural competence etc.).

This course forces you to think in a different way than other FES courses. There is a lot of self reflection. It lets you really dive deeply into softer skills that are extremely important but often overlooked in academia.
amazing wealth of knowledge about myself and how to manage teams (very valuable)
Better strategies for having difficult conversations, giving feedback, being a member of a team, knowing my strengths and weaknesses and how they play off others' strengths and weaknesses.
I am able to significantly better explain my own personal strengths and weaknesses.
Learned a lot about myself (strengths, weaknesses and how to improve) and how to work well in teams. Very useful skill set to hone.
Great insight into identifying my best self, thinking about working with people through different frameworks the course lecturers provided
Current research in psychology how to better work with teams.
The first part of the course, where we learn how we work as an individual and reflect on and get feedback on our strengths and weaknesses, was the most valuable.
Learned how personal connections and relationships can make me a better person and aid in the advancement of my career. Learned how to operate in different organizational structures.

The course was very useful. I learned a lot about myself and how to relate with other people in the professional environment. Also I obtained different tools I plan to use during my time at FES and my professional career such as recommendations for giving and receiving feedback, cooperation and network strategies and a decision-making tool through an online simulation.

I became more aware of my strengths and weaknesses as person, a team member, and a team leader. With that, this course helped me identify strategies for finding the conditions that will help bring out my best self, for managing teams, and for creating team dynamics, partnerships, and network connections that will produce innovative and productive results.

I got a better sense of concepts related to working with people. It was interesting to learn how people from different fields and with different trajectories conceptualized approaches to improving how we work with others. I also enjoyed being grouped into a Pod. It was nice to interact regularly with a small group of my peers.

This course was hugely helpful in pushing me to think about my own strengths and weaknesses, how to put them to use in professional and personal settings, and how to work well in teams and across networks. All invaluable skills moving back into the working world!
Great personal skills

The first third of the course was spent on learning about ourselves - our strengths, weaknesses, and working styles. The second part of the course was spent on how to build strong teams, and the third part put it all together. I learned a lot about different work and management styles, and I learned a great deal about myself and how I operate.

This course brought my attention to the importance of People as key drivers of change at all levels of individual and organizational life. The course showed the importance of team working and how it could change any organization in a long term. I also learned how to use the network tools to discover how change can be made to occur in an organization.
Matched exactly what I thought it would be.

I am inspired to think deeper on who I am, how to bring my best self, how to deal with people of opposite personality, and I am equipped with a suite of vocabularies and theories to articulate what I can bring to the team.
Somewhat
I wish there was more - so many classes left me feeling 'meh'. (While other classes - the ones I mentioned above - were absolutely stellar)
Better than I expected, especially in the beginning with the individual profile analysis.
I think I was hoping for more opportunities to somehow apply the skills we discussed and read about, but overall, I think the course aligned with my expectations.
Pretty well. I enjoyed overall but had trouble making it a priority.

I thought the class was really well taught. The speakers and readings were really well chosen and the  way that the material was presented in class was well done. This is a very difficult concept to teach and I thought Brad and Stuart provided useful and diverse templates for how to work well with people.
Not very well.
medium.
Very well - the class was what I expected and perhaps even better.
About equal.

I do think I expected slightly more hard skills to come-- ie more things like 'ways to give feedback.' I think some of the skills were geared to people in management positions, which won't be very relevant to many students for a few years. I wish we had a segment on ways to manage up.

Very well. Before taking the course, I was told that it was relatively low input but still useful, and I agree with that.  I appreciated that such a large portion of the course was dedicated to understanding ourselves before launching into theories related to team work. It was fun and useful to get personalized feedback and input on how we work with people.
This class did not meet my expectations.
It definitely exceeded my expectations because I was able to personalize it and draw on what was most relevant to me.

I thought we would have more "skills" or hands on type lectures, rather than idea or theory based. The theory based content was still useful, but I would have liked more things such as the hurricane simulation or sunglasses exercise.
Very well.
better than expected

It was about what I expected. The course material seemed more straightforward and "common sense" at its core than I had expected, but the skills I learned are certainly useful for the future as a professional.
I learned as much as I expected to.
Average

The class did not meet my expectation. I heard good reviews from some students last year and was disappointed that the class didn't deliver what I expected. In the second half of the course, speakers were hit or miss, the sessions felt disconnected, some of the insights from the speaker or discussion were just common sense and not useful.
Pretty well, in that I just had expectations on how improving my interpersonal skills and learning more about how to operate in an organization could help achieve my goals.

The course exceeded my expectations! I enjoyed most of the exercises and lectures of the course, particularly the discovery insights profile and the hurricane simulation.  The instructors made a great work with the selection of guest speaker and exercises.

I think that the class provided less structured formulas or techniques, so to speak, around these topics of 'working with people', but rather, hosted speakers that have experience studying or practicing with various aspects of working with people. They would then discuss their perspective and often promote discussion.
Well in terms of the material covered. I didn't have many expectations about the structure of the sessions.
Most of this course exceeded my expectations (i.e. I found it super useful), although there were individual speakers/classes that were not particularly helpful.
Yes
Yes!
The knowledge and skills from this class were very relevant in helping me frame some decisions.

I think having more simulations, such as the hurricane exercise, could be an interesting addition to the course. It helps apply lessons into real world situations and helps to facilitate a better discussion afterwards.

Strength:
Fun and interactive activities, e.g. hurricane exercise
provoke the students to think about how to handle relationship in new ways
Very philosophical

Weakness:
Class starts too early...

I was able to get a lot of value from this class because of the papers and the discovery profile. The guest speakers were a hit or miss. Some were really good, others not so much. 

I wish we had done pods earlier in the semester and had more pod discussions early on.

I would have liked more opportunities to put some of the concepts into practice, rather than sitting and listening to lectures every class.

Useful material for the most part, though some guest speakers were more valuable and engaging than others.

More opportunities for student engagement would be useful, and some way to ensure that students come to class prepared and having done the readings. 

Did a good job bringing in many different guest speakers, but the class overall felt a bit disjointed. I wish we had discussed certain issues, such as gender and race, in more meaningful ways. The unconscious bias class was completely inadequate, and many subsequent speakers didn't address these issues whatsoever. Good class, but needed more framing to come together in a cohesive way. 

Also, I wish the pods were actually used for something beyond the emergency exercise. Seemed like a lost opportunity.

Strengths: speakers who bring in lots of wisdom
Weaknesses: some classes/speakers didn't really teach me anything I didn't know

To improve, I guess I would think very intentionally and vet every speaker/topic.

Strengths - great interaction, diverse speakers, so many different perspectives to work off of when building and managing teams.

Weaknesses - there were so many fun activities in the beginning that died out at the end. It would be great for something more interactive, such as the color card game where everyone migrates around the room and shares different cards with people, should continue.

Strengths- the first unit and the last unit were very helpful and applicable. I think the second unit was less applicable to students who focus on environmental issues. In addition, I didn't think the pods were useful or helpful at all. And then we had to give our podmates feedback at the end but had only really done one activity (the hurricane exercise) together. Also, I think it would make more sense to do reading responses than to do 4 page reflection papers. A person can only talk about their feelings for so long. Finally, are there more opportunities for us to engage with women and people of color? I would also recommend cutting the restaurant case study in unit 2 (that was really not applicable and also kind of sexist).
I'm not sure what can be done other than forcing more engagement. This class ended up being a low priority, but I'm not certain of how to fix that.

I wish the class size had been smaller because I think this type of class needs thoughtful discussion throughout it and, while we were able to get that type of discussion sometimes, our discussion time was often relatively short because we had to hear from so many groups. I really enjoyed the course content and wished we had a little more time to discuss each aspect both in our pods and also as a class. I think a smaller class size would have allowed for that. I also feel like many students should take this course and wonder if it could be split into multiple smaller recitations with one large lecture taught on one day and smaller recitations taught by either Brad or Stuart on another.
I thought the course itself could be slightly lacking in direction. Prepping the various guest lecturers on sticking to the syllabus or their particular message would have been appreciated.

It would have been useful to not have a speaker in each class (though thanks for the effort!!) and have a couple of classes off to be able to reflect collectively in what we have learned. Also this could have helped us assess our classmates with a little bit more insight, since as it stands now it was difficult to assess them.
More engagement with assigned readings.

The speakers were by and large (75%) outstanding. The remaining were either not engaging or felt the content they shared was not especially useful. Amy and Valerie were by far my favorite lecturers. 

I thought the hurricane exercise and change management simulation were very useful and insightful. I would have like to have more of that in the class.

Some of the discussions were stopped short and I wish we could have developed it further. Discussions as a large class can be difficult to manage, but the smaller group discussions were often not as engaging. The topics discussed were very open ended and it was sometimes unclear how I should approach them going forward - there was not always a consensus on what the best action would be for a given issue.
Excellent teaching team. SOME guest speakers were good, some were really not good. If someone shows an all white male "team building" video again I think the entire student body will lose it.

Strengths: It was very clear that guest speakers worked to make their sessions engaging and interactive. I found Amy Wrzesniewski and Sarah Biggerstaff particularly engaging. 

Weaknesses: It would have been useful to work on more simulations or actual team work with our pod. I thought we were going to work a lot more with them, but mainly we were grouped just for discussions.

I think one of the strengths of the course is that it draws a diverse group of students. I think it has a number of weaknesses. First, there was too much of a business focus. For example, why not have an anthropologist speak to the class? They work with people too, and often in far more challenging settings than a CEO. Farrell was the only sociologist that spoke, and he could have offered a unique perspective on working with people, but instead he gave a very abstract lecture on his research. I would have liked if the class was less theoretical and academic and more about providing students with hands-on experience with working with people. What would this look like? What about working with other students, especially our pod-mates? For example, the most challenging experience I had working with a person was when we did the computer simulation. There was a lot of friction between me and my partner even though that wasn't even the point of the exercise. Working through that friction could have been a really amazing learning experience. My suggestion would be for Foundations of Working with People to think a bit outside the box in terms of pedagogy. For example, maybe each pod could do one of the Escape rooms in Escape New Haven. The students have 1 hour to work together to get out of the room. In my opinion, that would be more valuable than doing the personality test at the beginning of the semester. That would be an incredible learning experience in terms of working with others under a time pressure.

Guest Speakers were all fantastic in sharing their knowledge and insights. The teaching team also really complemented each other. 
The simulations were great and would recommend more of those.

The class would benefit from having a session every few weeks WITHOUT a guest speaker, where students and teaching team could discuss the material and guest lectures. It often didn't feel like a cohesive class because we jumped from one guest to another without any time for considering their talks in unison. I don't think the reflection papers served this purpose very well, and I would have liked to talk about it with my pod or with Brad/Stu/Katie/Ross.

Great guest lecturers! Great teaching team! My main suggestion would be that if you are going to use the pods again next year I suggest doing more actual exercises with them or not use them at all. I also think having each pod provide an answer to different discussion questions can get somewhat repetitive and boring. I would rather have the people that want to speak just raise their hands in class discussions rather than forcing each pod to provide an answer. I think the discussions would be more lively that way. I think it's great to have the pods talk amongst themselves about their thoughts but I don't think every pod needs to report back every time. 

This course requires a lot of written reflections. These can feel tedious but if you really spend time on them the reflection can be very beneficial, especially as you approach the working world.

Insights Discovery Profiles are super interesting and helpful! I love thinking more deliberately about what my skills and weaknesses are. 

I think the set up of case studies was a little strange. I preferred when guest lecturers would just come in and give a more traditional lecture about their experiences related to the topic. I think it would also be good to tell some of the lecturers to talk for less time about the specifics of their work and more about how their experiences relate to the given module.
more pod work, less intimidation to speak up in front of large group

Strengths: easy to comprehend, learn, and do; good for knowing oneself and how oneself can fit into a team with others; clearly useful and applicable immediately.

Weaknesses: straightforwardness lends itself to stagnation, class was boring at times. Relevant learning from irrelevant case studies made it harder to take those lessons and apply them to our arenas.
Not enough discussion time after each presenter.

The first two modules were very helpful, but the third was lacking in useful/interesting content. Some of the speakers - Such as Ony and Amy  - were rockstars - and others - like Peter - were less so. Hopefully professors/TAs can screen the speakers next year based on their performance this time around. Another weakness: the exercises seemed to be graded arbitrarily. I put equal amount of effort in to each assignment -submitted my best work each time - never received full points. Was never given an actual explanation as to why I didn't receive full points. (Seems petty, but how are we supposed to know what you're looking for/how to do better, if it isn't made explicit for the entire class?) Discussions of cross-racial interactions were light-touch and unhelpful.

Receiving the Discovery Insights profile and feedback from past colleagues, and friends was really helpful. I learned a lot about how others perceived my work and it helped me identify where I could improve myself throughout the semester. One weakness was some of the guest lecturers. Specifically, Rodrigo Canales, who was dismissive towards student comments, and generally abrasive. It was not appreciated that he commanded students stay after class to hear the end of his presentation. It was uncomfortable and he is not an example of someone who is good at working with people. He should not be invited again. A second weakness is that the course only talks about positive examples of working with people and does not spend enough time discussing how to navigate the many challenges of working with people. This is a missed opportunity to use class discussions to talk about real challenges we face and how to address them. The pods could be used to facilitate more group discussion and providing support for specific challenges fellow pod-mates face throughout the course of the semester; particularly, since the pods are a mix of different Insights profile types.

This class should be condensed into a 1.5 or 2 credit course. Again, the first part of the course was great (Amy Wrzesniewski was amazing, especially with her talk about the purpose of work and how we should think about our job and career after FES), the Hurricane exercise was good, some speakers in the latter half like Justin Farrell and Peter Boyd were good. The instructors should review speakers who came this year and cut out the ones that were flat. Also, speakers should talk about the skills that we can take to apply to our own work instead of simply describing their work, which was narrow and not relevant to students.

Strengths - the diversity of speakers that came in to share their expertise on their specific topics. The simulations we did - the hurricane exercise, the organization computer game, etc - were really fun, and really demonstrative of the modules that we did. I really liked the pods concept - getting to work with the same group over a period of time is definitely what we're going to be doing in the future.

The class has many strengths, including the content, the materials, the guest-speakers and the division by pods. Specially the work in pods was beneficial to me because I was not ready to speak in front of the hole class, but I could share my ideas with the members of my team and engaged in class discussions. Also, I really like having the class twice a week. 
I would change the time of the class. I am not a morning person, so it was very hard for me to be on time. I would have preferred to have such an enjoyable course later in the day.

The strengths of this course are it makes the case that soft skills are the hardest to master and it gives you a space to reflect on your strengths, weaknesses, and areas where you want to improve and build on. The weakness for me is that the guest speakers could be less familiar with the FES students' backgrounds and provide more background than is necessary, based on our baseline understanding of certain topics. Some speakers gave more relevant and memorable lectures than others. I think the reflections were helpful for us to reflect on what we learned and extract the useful elements of the lectures. It could be improved by asking speakers to minimize background information and re-state the key takeaways at the end of their talks.

Another area of improvement that became clear from one lecture in particular was that the readings were not always relevant, so there were times when I would spend time and energy doing the readings, but they were not useful or necessary for lectures, while other times, the readings or videos were critical. Sometimes it's hard as a student to know what to prioritize, when there are so many other competing interests for our time. I think it was very helpful when the TF's would make a Canvas announcement when the readings or videos would be particularly important for in-class discussion, because this helped make sure enough students do the reading to have a functional discussion.

Strength and weakness: There where many speakers from a wide variety of fields. These allowed us to receive information from different perspectives from people who are experts in their fields. However, the presentations were not very articulated. We reflected on the presentations individually in our papers, which was a way for us to connect them personally. Nevertheless, it would have been nice to have opportunities to reflect about their connections in class.

The first section of this course, which focuses on self awareness and understanding, was by far the best. The Insights Discovery Profile we completed was extremely helpful, and all of the speakers I can remember in that section were fabulous. The teamwork and network sections were a little more hit or miss, but still generally helpful.
Great class- too many guest speakers. Liked the exercises a lot more.

Strengths:
- the self-reflection exercises we did. The Insights Discovery Profile was my favorite assignment. I learned so much about myself, and I've already used what I learned to help me in interviews. 
- many of the guest lectures were fascinating. The course was structured in such a way that the lectures built off the body of knowledge we gained in previous lectures. The teaching team clearly thought a lot about who they wanted to have speak, and they did a great job.
- The teaching team - Brad and Stu work really well together and bring a great energy to the course. Ross and Katie were awesome TAs, and always available to help and answer questions.
- the readings were usually really interesting

Weaknesses:
- The lecture by Rodrigo from SOM was not my favorite (not a class fan favorite either)
Take it!
Definitely taking this course before you graduate!!!

Interesting class, useful material to think about when preparing to enter the workplace. Less work required than other FES classes, and a different kind of work with personal reflections rather than research papers.

Come up with a list of goals you wish to achieve in your professional and even personal relationships. There is a good chance those things will be covered. If you feel like the material does not address your needs, tell Stu or Brad immediately. They are great with course flexibility so that students get the most of the experience.

I think it is a great course, but the opportunity to apply the lessons learned really falls on you. I would also consider it a good "balancing class" because it definitely uses a different part of your brain than FES science or "Technical" courses.

Might be more of a final semester course. I would only suggest taking if you've had real problems working in groups or are interested in a career in facilitating or management design problem solving. Otherwise, you can probably spend use credits better elsewhere.

This class provides several templates and real world examples for how to work with people which is an essential skill that any environmental manager will need to know how to do. Brad and Stuart do a wonderful job bringing in guest lecturers with many different backgrounds and provide a great deal of insight from their own lives. This is a very worthwhile course!
Do the readings.
Take it. THIS SHOULD BE A CORE CLASS!
Take it! Many undervalue the importance of the types of soft skills and tactics you learn in this class but believe me, it is so worth it.
Best to take in your last semester!

I would recommend this course. The lectures are interesting and it provides you with dedicated time to step back and think about how you work with people and what your strengths and weaknesses are. This course was a nice reprieve from classes focused on environmental topics.

The way this course was structured made it an easy and sometimes enjoyable course. I would take it only if you are looking to lighten your workload. Occasionally, there are some really cool speakers. Other times, the speakers are mediocre. I wouldn't go out of your way to take the course.
Be open, listen and participate!
Be flexible
This class uses a different part of your brain than other FES classes. Very useful for second years.
Grading is somewhat arbitrary so make sure to ask how to get full points for every assignment.

This is a good class to have in the final semester when you are busy with recruiting and interviewing. The class covers some important soft skills and will give you insight into your working styles, strengths and weaknesses. I did not have time to do the reading but you will learn more if you do the reading.
Take this course if you're a person! It'll make you better understand how best to operate in any organization to achieve your goals and to advance your career.
It is a great course. I highly recommend taking it in the first year to put in practice the skills and tools you will get during the course.
Take it if you want to get an overview of different concepts and approaches related to working with people.

People definitely slack on this class. If you're going to get the most out of it I recommend doing the readings, going to class, and taking the time to think about speakers etc. Otherwise it's not worth it!
great class

This is a great course, and unique at FES. The focus on the "soft skills" isn't something we get a lot of at FES, but I would argue that for people at a professional school, it's a critical skill set to acquire. We should value people skills equally to quantitative science. As environmental managers, working with teams of people is going to be our career reality, and we need to be prepared for the diversity and challenges working in teams poses. 

I was warned before I took the class not to forget about the readings, and I wish I had heeded this advice. I started out very strong in the beginning of the semester. I completed each reading and did it well, but after spring break, that really took a nosedive. It's easy not to do them because you aren't held accountable for it in class, but they really do augment the quality of the course and help you in your learning. Do them!
It is a good class to sharpen your people skills and develop your personal potentials.
